reasoning: The critique targets a potential downstream implication/rhetorical hazard (“this could license radical intervention/utopian purges”), which is only moderately connected to the paper’s core thesis that near-best futures are a narrow target; even if the hazard claim were defused, the paper’s central argument about moral fussiness could still stand (centrality ~0.3). As a refutation of the position, it is weak: it does not engage the paper’s object-level claims (e.g., multiplicative fragility, fat-tailed value-efficiency, bounded vs unbounded views) and largely shifts from truth of the thesis to misuse risks (strength ~0.1). Some parts are plausible (any “perfect vs good” framing can be misused), but it contains key exaggerations/misreadings: the paper does not straightforwardly label an abundant, consensual world as “near-zero value,” and it does not argue that destruction is justified; it explicitly distinguishes “far short of best” from “worse than extinction” and flags moral uncertainty (correctness ~0.4). The point is clearly stated and focused (clarity high; single-issue high). Little is pure filler, though the rhetoric is heavy (dead weight low). Overall it poses a limited, mostly external critique rather than a substantive undermining of the argument.
title: Demanding perfection over goodness licenses destructive utopian interventions
